Below is a “back‑of‑the‑envelope” calculation that turns the per‑unit‑electricity death rates quoted in the previous answer into an estimate of **total premature deaths over the 30‑year lifetime of a 1 GW‑capacity plant**.  
The numbers are meant to illustrate the *order of magnitude* of the difference; they are not precise predictions for any specific facility.

## 1. How much electricity does a 1 GW plant actually produce?

| Plant type | Typical capacity factor* | Annual electricity (TWh) | 30‑year electricity (TWh) |
|------------|--------------------------|--------------------------|---------------------------|
| Coal       | 0.70 – 0.80 (average ≈ 0.75) | 1 GW × 0.75 × 8 760 h ≈ 6.6 TWh | 6.6 × 30 ≈ 197 TWh |
| Nuclear    | 0.85 – 0.95 (average ≈ 0.90) | 1 GW × 0.90 × 8 760 h ≈ 7.9 TWh | 7.9 × 30 ≈ 236 TWh |

*Capacity factor = the fraction of time the plant runs at its rated power. Coal plants are limited by fuel‑supply, maintenance and market dispatch; nuclear plants are usually run as baseload and have higher availability.*

---

## 2. Apply the life‑cycle death‑rate estimates

| Source of deaths | Deaths / TWh (mid‑point of the ranges in the first table) | 30‑year deaths for a 1 GW plant |
|------------------|------------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------|
| **Coal – air‑pollution + occupational** | **≈ 25 deaths / TWh** (≈ 10–40 range) | 25 × 197 ≈ 4 900 deaths |
| **Nuclear – full life‑cycle (including rare accidents)** | **≈ 0.05 deaths / TWh** (≈ 0.02–0.2 range) | 0.05 × 236 ≈ 12 deaths |

### Putting the ranges on the table

| Plant | Low‑end estimate (best‑case) | Mid‑point (most‑cited) | High‑end estimate (pessimistic) |
|-------|------------------------------|------------------------|---------------------------------|
| **Coal** | 10 × 197 ≈ 2 000 deaths | **≈ 5 000 deaths** | 40 × 197 ≈ 7 900 deaths |
| **Nuclear** | 0.02 × 236 ≈ 5 deaths | **≈ 12 deaths** | 0.20 × 236 ≈ 47 deaths |

*The “high‑end” nuclear figure includes a relatively generous weighting of the long‑term health impact of the Chernobyl and Fukushima accidents. Even that upper bound is still **two orders of magnitude lower** than the low‑end coal estimate.*
